text:

TELEGRAPHIC.
CHIT-CHAT LOCALS.

(By Special Telegraph.)
Gathered by our Reporter.

Next Tuesday will be Queen's Birthday.

Fifth for Boots, Shoes and Slippers.

Precaution against cold.

D. Petersen arrived at the last mail, after spending a pleasant holiday in Ontario.

Mr. and Mrs. H. J. Montgomery are home from the east on Tuesday evening last.

The P. A. Cricket Club are practising hard for the coming match with the Police Club on the Queen's Birthday.

A few trees were planted on Arbor Day, but the majority of the people had other plans for the day.

Preparations are being made for a grand celebration of the Queen's jubilee and Dominion Day on the 31st July.

Chief Justice David Ross of St. Albans, has been appointed Clerk of the Court for the District of Saskatchewan.

Headmaster Pocket Dunn came by last mail and brought with him a full of useful information to the travelling public.

Two buildings in connection with the new barracks are under way and over sixty men are employed. The barracks will consist of three two-story buildings.

Courses throughout the district are looking exceedingly well, and the indications are that this season's harvest will be the best bought the farmers have reaped for years.

A banquet in aid of the building fund of Our Lady Roman Catholic Church, will take place at the Roman Catholic Hall, Thursday, the 1st and 2nd of June. Further particulars next week.

Grasshoppers have formed a partner with George Melchett in the Victoria Livery and Sale Stable, and the firm have got in new signs and fresh paintwork, which they say will be sold at reasonable rates, night and day.

Mr. Smith, the pilot of the North Star, arrived at the Canadian Camp last Monday. He had not been heard from when he started, but it was expected she would be ready for the return trip early next week. She will leave in a few days for Grand Rapids.

Chief Factor Bellanger, of Cumberland House, visited the St. Ann's Church last week. After a long, pleasant and hour spent in recreation, music, etc., Mr. Bellanger returned thanks to the parishioners for their kindness and hospitality for the very pleasant entertainment they had given, expressing pleasure at the manner in which the church was being made in the several departments.

A pilgrim who struck town the other day for the first time states that he had nothing but Boone county if he had known what a beautiful fertile country it was. He said that he could see the corn over two thousand in farming in Assiniboia and would not be bound to show pity to any but should show that corn will not grow in a desert no more than pigs will on thorns.

All we need is a way to secure our land titles.

The Northwest Farmer for May says—
"The Prince Albert Times, quoting the statement of Mr. Bellanger, that agriculture in the Northwest is grateful to know why seeding should be recommended so early as the end of May, if not earlier, says, 'It takes about six weeks to mature, surely it is wisest to take these weeks when the soil has least moisture, as it is actually useless to sow grain that is best not by seeding so late as to keep it from when the plant is at its weakest.' From this statement the Farmer says that it took fourteen weeks for flat to mature, and we took it at its worst. It is also stated that when spring crops are injured in this country, but when the grain is ripening, so much so that it is easy to see that it is injured, and if it is easy to see that it is injured from other crops when maturing all the sooner."

We care you give Fast a call for the cheapest and best Boot and Shoe ever offered in the town.
HOUSE OF COMMONS

Some discussion took place on the 4th of May on the question of the Government's action in India. The Opposition, under Governor Macdonald, was opposed to the proposal, while the Government contended that the situation required immediate action. The debate continued until late into the evening.

The next day, the House of Commons met again to discuss the same issue. The Opposition, led by Mr. Macdonald, argued that the situation in India demanded prompt action. The Government, however, maintained that the proposal was unnecessary and would cause further complications.

On the 6th, Sir Charles Tupper introduced a motion to adjourn the House until the 15th. This motion was defeated, and the House continued its discussion on the India issue.

The following day, the House of Commons met again to vote on the India bill. The Opposition, led by Mr. Macdonald, argued against the bill, citing concerns about the potential consequences. The Government, however, defended the bill, emphasizing its importance.

The debate continued until late into the evening, with both sides presenting their arguments. The House finally adjourned until the 15th.

THE PRINCE ALBERT TIMES

Sir Charles Tupper made his budget speech on May 15th, announcing the government's plans for the upcoming fiscal year. The budget included significant increases in military spending, as well as cuts to social programs.

The government also announced plans to expand the Canadian Pacific Railway, with the aim of connecting the country from coast to coast. The railway was expected to create thousands of jobs and stimulate economic growth.

The budget also included measures to address the country's growing debt, with the government promising to reduce the deficit over the next five years.

THE NEW YORK TIMES

Sir Charles Tupper delivered a speech on May 15th, outlining the government's plans for the upcoming fiscal year. The budget included significant increases in military spending, as well as cuts to social programs.

The government also announced plans to expand the Canadian Pacific Railway, with the aim of connecting the country from coast to coast. The railway was expected to create thousands of jobs and stimulate economic growth.

The budget also included measures to address the country's growing debt, with the government promising to reduce the deficit over the next five years.

THE CANADIAN PRESS

Sir Charles Tupper delivered a speech on May 15th, outlining the government's plans for the upcoming fiscal year. The budget included significant increases in military spending, as well as cuts to social programs.

The government also announced plans to expand the Canadian Pacific Railway, with the aim of connecting the country from coast to coast. The railway was expected to create thousands of jobs and stimulate economic growth.

The budget also included measures to address the country's growing debt, with the government promising to reduce the deficit over the next five years.
A meeting of the Organization Commit-tee in connection with the proposed celebration of the Queen's Jubilee will take place this evening in the Council Chamber. All members of the Commit-tee should be present.

TERRITORIAL NEWS

EDMONTON

From the Bulletin, April 28th.

A large amount of last year's grain still remains in the farmer's hands.

H. A. L. Dandridge, of the Calgary Land Office, is Chief of the Land Court, the judicial district of Northern Alberta.

C. Delagrange, of St. Albert, has been appointed Clerk of the Court for the judicial district of Southern Alberta.

Arrangements are now being made by the Postoffice Department to run a fortnightly mail to Victoria after May 1st.

Rev. Mr. McCallum has purchased property and the name of the postoffice to be Pakan.

P. Daly has opened a private banking business in the building occupied by him as a drug store.

BATTLEFORD

From the Herald, April 30th.

The telegraph construction party to operate here and Pitt will be gin work on Monday. It is composed entirely of young people.

The experiment of mining tried this week at the mouth of Battle River was crowned with complete success, as no less than two hundred pounds of gold was taken at one haul. The kinks taken comprise half a dozen varieties, from the conglomerate to the alluvial.

A hurricane from the west visited this section on Wednesday, and brought down a prairie fire that had been started for some time. The fire swept through the town at lightning speed and had all but caught in Mr. Clark's hay stacks who had had his hands full trying to get out to fight the fire. Had it once got hold of the hay nothing could save the town.

GENERAL NEWS

CANADIAN

Mount Rose, of Regina, who have just returned from the Wood Mountain District, report that a band of five hun-dred cattle belonging to the Wood Mountain Ranch, near the town of Milk River country. This herd was supposed to have perished during the heavy snowstorms of last winter.

The Royal Canadian Academy, Mon-treal, closed on the 7th.

Sir Wm. Young, ex-chief justice, died at Halifax, N.S., on April 26th.

The recent scoundrel discoveries in the Quebec Mercury libel suit regarding the way conductors have been lied by politicians have led to the demand for a royal commission enquiry.

A drowning accident occurred at Ma-gpie, Qu'Appelle, by which three people lost their lives.

The Governor General and Lady Lans-downe held a reception at Government House, Toronto, May 7th.

Yakima, an Indian, was maliciously shot and killed on a reserve near Dalhousie, Man., on the 7th, by an Indian named Thomas.

St. John, N.B., has been visited by a severe flood.

Pov, Gunner, T. E., died suddenly at Ottawa on the 6th.

Vancouver will celebrate the Queen's birthday on Dominion Day.

The Canadian Manufacturer comes out strongly against Mr. Wilkie's proposal for commercial union.

Work will be commenced immediately on the South St. Marie bridge.

The strike, caused by the stonecutters' strike, Toronto, has been broken, several of the masters having given in.

The Liberal country press throughout Ontario is in favour of immediate action in regard to the men in the Toronto shipyard.

Byron Landry, of Montreal, was drowned while swimming near Almonte, on the 6th.

Tridel, chief of the water police, Qu'Appelle, is the second victim of acts of perjury.

J. K. MacNeil, North-Westerner R.R., was murdered by a man named Shaw.

A terrific wind swept the country near St. Vincent, Man., last week, wrecking buildings and demolishing chimneys.

AMERICAN AND FOREIGN.

No credence is given to the reported Franco-Russian alliance in English min-isterial circles.

The French trans Atlantic steamer La Champlain collided with the steamer Ville de Rio, near Havre. The pas-sengers and all cargo were saved.

Nearly two million pounds of tea were sent from Hiago, Japan, to the Canadian Pacific terminus last year.

The Australian colonies have resolved upon a common treaty to exclude French convicts from admission to Australia until France abandons her plans in re-gard to the settlement of New Hibernia.

A meeting of the Colonial Conference was held on the 9th, at which a resolu-tion relative to laying of the sub-marine cable between Vancouver and Aus-tralia were agreed to.

At London a handsome calf in a stable, Hammersmith railway station, was killed by a collision with a van. Flying crawled out of four limbs.

The Chinese government have ordered that every foreign missionary in China must hold a passport from his own Gov-ernment in order to show his nationality.

Gladstone gave a banquet on the 7th at which Earl Spencer, Baron Wolse-ley, T. T. Sullivan, Justin McCarthy, and several English, Irish and Scotch members of Parliament were present.

THE FOX CHEATED.

From the Press for the Times.

A fox rushed for persimmons (this fruit is much relished at the foot of a tree. He was about to throw himself upon her when he heard the noise of a drum somewhere near. It was the branch of a tree which vibrated by the violence of the wind, were moving more. "Oh, Oh," the fox thought, raising his head. "Are there any fellows around?" "Who ever you are, by the noise you make you seem to have more feet on you than a dog. That is very extraordinary. I have eaten so many that I have had the gout for a long time. You shall have none of mine." "I have eaten so many that I have had the gout for a long time. You shall have none of mine."

The prudent man does not quit the real for the imaginary. That which is most solid, neither the most advan-tageous.

Season 1887

THOS. SCOTT'S STABLES,

At the Ridge.

Season commences April 27th and ends July 3rd.

Poscorron is noted as the finest roadster in the North Western Territories. Is of the breed known as the French Canadian. Harris Street, Que., 17 years old. Was given to the celebrated French Canadian horse trainer, Mr. Gerfond, by Mr. Scott in 1877, and was sold at the age of 21.

MOORE & MACDOWALL.
THE BATTLE OF RATOCHIE

Last Thursday was the second anniversary of the storming of Ratochie by the troops under Sir Frederick Middleton, and we thought it would be a good idea to pay our respects to those who fell in the battle, and to give them publicity, recalling and commemorating, as they ought to be, the brave men worthy of remembrance. It will be remembered that Ratochie was attacked on the 12th of May, and the battle closed on the 13th, after three days hard fighting.

The day before the fight they sought
With skill and shot,
Their foe to slay.
From out their lair
They came not forth.
Three days I say,
They marched away
To seek the fray.
The drive from out
Their stronghold,
Backward rolled
Nor scarcely knew
Their way.
Those western men,
Ratocchie's sons,
Their friends beside,
And none behind.
Another night,
Again the light
Was seen to rise.
The "forward" sounds
And bugles blare,
Into the fray.
Through broken bread
They came to race.
South led the hall;
West came the star.
The sounds of war
Were heard afar.
...a third to fight
With all their might
And all their will.
Though friends be foes
And brothers die,
They all shall die.
And they have sworn
A solemn oath
On the field below.
Interlocked they fall.
Interlocked they fall.
So they sped,
Thus came of red
And black.
While each wild note
Was heard.
They answered loud.
Once drew the share
Of death and pain.
While horror still
The earth did fill
As dust and dust
Interlocked they fall.
Then came the wind
Each man its hand—
And thus they came
And with it died.
Poveshell's sword
Then they returned
Soon sank the star
That shone so fair.
That western sky
Above the strife
The flag was flung.

HENRY T. McINTYRE

TOWN COUNCIL.

An adjourned meeting of the Town Council took place last evening. Present—Councillors Agnew, Bain, Buttenher and Stewart.

The minutes of the last meeting were read and adopted.

COMMUNICATIONS

were received from Mr. Woodman concerning land sales license and Percy Domingo concerning Catholic cemetery.

J. L. Sabinson & Co., No. 85; and J. D. Marcey, $40.50. Adopted.

J. L. Sabinson, Chairman of the Finance and Assessment Committee, reported that the sum of $300 had been granted the Lower Agricultural Society, said money to be used in purchasing land or erecting permanent buildings.

It was also that the following resolutions be adopted:

J. L. Sabinson & Co., No. 85; and J. D. Marcey, $40.50. Adopted.

The Special Committee appointed to confer with the Board of Works and to secure a building ground report series.

Councillor Bain reported that he would introduce a by-law to build and maintain sewers, drains, ditches and water courses.

The Council then adjourned.

Murder or Suicide?

Peter Smith Found Dead near His House with a Bullet Hole in His Head.

End Play Suspected.

Peter Smith, who at one time carried on a bakery in Prince Albert, was found dead near his residence, about two miles north of Touchwood Hills, by some freighters, on the 6th inst.

December 1st being a stopping station, Peter Smith visited Prince Albert, and was living entirely alone, his only companion being two faithful dogs. The next morning he started early in the day on his way to Prince Albert, who, on arriving at the stopping place, found the body lying on the ground.

Thinking it strange that the house should be open and trembled he made a search of the premises, but could find nothing except his clothes, which were neatly hung up.

He then proceeded to the scene of the tragedy, and with some difficulty on account of the snow, succeeded in raising the body of the deceased, and was immediately sent to Dr. Doll, of Q.Apple, to come and see what could be done.

Mr. Wm. Dewey, of Prince Albert, who was on his way here, also saw the body, and made a thorough examination of the dogs, to ascertain if closely. He also states that he was warned on his way home by Q.Apple by Mr. Buttenher to look out for strange looking dogs near the Salt Plains.

For weeks Peter Smith refused to disclose any facts connected with the case, whether deceased met with foul play or took his own life. The fact that he was parted with his wife and children, and had no particular friend, while the fact that a string was attached to the trigger of the gun, and that the bullet hole in the mouth would suggest suicide. It is possible, however, that the string attached to the gun may have been there for the purpose of hanging the weapon on the wall, and that the deceased meant that he was about to commit suicide. He had been very ill for some time, and had been confined to bed for some time, and to this fact and his lonely state of life is doubted that the string was there. He was a bachelor, was in Winnipeg, and was an Englishman by birth, though he had been in Canada for some years.

Boston Young Lady—Yes, sir, while visiting in the country last summer, I met a young gentleman, whom I never want to forget.

Dealer—May I ask what that—er—gentleman was?

Boston Young Lady—Oh, yes, I made a fumblesteak for a blackberry.

The new American has been more honest with dinner, and has been less butter flick, creaked back and lazy legs upon the table.

It is said that the ex Express Engineer still bears the traces of great and delicate feelings, almost resembling her age and mystery.

A man committed suicide the other day, and left a paper which he did not sign. The paper was not good for him. The jury thought this conclusion was correct, and that the man was in a state of delirium.

The Princess of Wales is always on the side of common sense, and is having her hair cut by a hairdresser. She is dressing, and has set aside to make a trip around the world that ought to be widely known.

Miss Susan Wood, who was recently awarded by the London University the teachers diploma in the art, theory and practice of teaching, is engaged to teach third year women who have won the distinction.

Patry's recent season in New York was a great financial success. The total result was $80,000.
